newsitem.title: USA: NY precious metals end sharply higher, funds cover.
newsitem.headline: NY precious metals end sharply higher, funds cover.

text.p: New York precious metals futures ended sharply higher Tuesday, helped by fund shortcovering as a six-week decline looked to be bottoming out, analysts said.
"The weekly momentums on December gold and silver and January platinum have all turned positive," Dorsey, Wright and Associates president Thomas Dorsey of Virginia said.
"We are beginning to see some gold stocks turn to positive weekly momentum also (in the Philadelphia Stock Exchange's gold and silver sector index) and that suggests a short term bounce."
COMEX December gold ended up $2.20 an ounce at $386.10, after trading up to a four week high at $386.50, on high estimated gold futures volume of 48,000 lots.

In New York bullion trade, spot gold ended quoted $383.90/384.40, its highest level since September 9, compared to the London Tuesday afternoon fix at $383.35 and the New York close Monday at $381.75/382.25.
COMEX December silver closed up 5.3 cents at $4.990 an ounce, after seeing an intraday high at $5.000.
NYMEX January platinum ended up $2.70 at $391.00, after seeing a ten day high at $391.30.
NYMEX December palladium gained $2.35 to $120.75, its highest level since October 7.
The Philadelphia Stock Exchange's gold and silver sector index ended was up 2.49 points at 119.13 near the close, a two week high for the index.

"We saw some fund buying and shortcovering on a breach of a downtrend line suggesting the six week old decline may be over and a breach of the 40 day moving average in December gold futures," Refco analyst Tim Porter said.
But it will take evidence of significant fund shortcovering to turn the downtrend around convincingly, analysts said. Resistance in December gold is now seen around $387.50 an ounce.

"There also appears to be a correlation between the equity market and the gold market in the short term, with gold benefitting from down days in the stockmarket like today recently," Imperial Bank's California-based chief bullion dealer Jeff Singer said.
COMEX warehouse stocks of gold and silver have been falling steadily in recent weeks also, with silver stocks seeing 10-year lows last week.
Wilmington Trust silver stocks also slipped further in the latest week to 58.223,976 ounces.
The decline in stocks is seen related to U.S. exports to Asia where Indian demand is seen rising seasonally.
India is the world's largest consumer of gold and demand is driven by three factors - wedding seasons, harvests and festivals.

Dealers said Indian gold demand would get a boost from the Hindu festival of Dassera on Monday and from the festival of Diwali on November 10-11. In the week ended last Saturday, gold prices rose 25 rupees per 10 grammes to 5,150 rupees on the Bombay gold market.
Finally, there may be a correlation between U.S. presidential election years and the gold market.
"In the last two election years, the precious metals sector has bottomed out in December of the election year and then reversed back up," Dorsey said.
--Clive Mckeef, New York Commodities 212-859-1641; email: clive.mckeef@reuters.com
